div.p: East (Mashreq) › Arabia › Yemen › Sanaa and central mountains

Ṣanʕāʔ, the capital of Yemen, is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world, and one of the world’s highest capital cities. The Old City of Ṣanʕāʔ, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is famous for its distinctive architecture – especially its multi-storey buildings decorated with geometric patterns.
Ṣanʕānī Arabic is the dialect of the original inhabitants of the Old City of Sanaa and its traditional suburbs, al-Bawniyah and al-Qāʕ (Qāʕ al-Yahūd).

The first study on the dialect of Sanaa was Rossi (1939). It is divided into sections on grammar, texts, and lexicon. The 46-page grammatical section includes information on phonology and morphology. The texts include phrases, dialogues, proverbs, narratives, and folk poetry.
Watson (1993) is a comprehensive study of the syntax of the dialect; and Watson (2000) a large collection of texts.

Naïm (2009) is a detailed examination of phonology and morphology and in the appendix offers information on women's speech. Behnstedt (2016) is an atlas showing the distribution of phonological, morphological, and lexical phenomena in the dialects of North Yemen, including that of Sanaa.
Watson’s "Ṣanʕānī Arabic" in EALL IV, 106-115 is a concise grammatical sketch of the dialect.

The most comprehensive dictionary of Yemeni Arabic is Piamenta (1990). Rossi (1939) includes a 57-page Italian-Arabic glossary. Huizinga (1984) is a 75-page English-Arabic glossary emphasizing medical terminology. Al-ʔIriyānī (1996) is a monolingual dictionary. Qafisheh (1990) includes both Arabic-English and English-Arabic glossaries. Naïm (2009) has a 10-page French-Arabic glossary.

Qafisheh (1990) is a textbook of Yemeni Arabic based on Ṣanʕānī Arabic: it consists of 40 lessons, each including a text with translation and sections of vocabulary, grammar, and exercises. Watson (1996) is a textbook specifically dedicated to Ṣanʕānī Arabic divided into 20 lessons, each with dialogues, vocabulary lists, grammar, and exercises.
SemArch contains the audio files of the texts in Watson (1996) and Watson (2000).
